doc.title: Trades closed over the past 12 months
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/United Kingdom Keep 10s30s gilt curve steepening biasUnited Kingdom Keep 10s30s gilt curve steepening bias_2025-08-29

passages.text: Figure 1: Gilt yields are modestly higher over the past two weeks and gilts have underperformed cross market vs. Bunds and, in particular, USTs Change in benchmark yields since 15 Aug, bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 2: We continue to receive Nov25 MPC OIS with 5bp of easing priced and a full 25bp cut only fully priced by March MPC OIS meeting date steps and cumulative easing priced (RHS), bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Domestic data over the past couple of weeks has increasingly challenged expectations of further BoE easing this year. Last week, headline CPI printed at \(3.8\%\) oya, in line with BoE expectations, but the underlying details showed sizeable price gains in food prices and core services, two categories the BoE is specifically focused on, with food inflation surprising to the upside in July \((4.9\%\) oya vs \(4.7\%\) BoE forecast). The PMI continues to indicate a weak jobs market, but the stronger than expected flash PMI for August suggests upside risks to our 3Q GDP forecast of \(0.8\%\) q/q annualised. GfK's consumer confidence reading for August also rose, suggesting household spending is not as weak as feared.

Our economist's call remains for a 25bp cut in November and a further 25bp cut in February, but we acknowledge the bar for a November ease has moved higher. We think a combination of a large downshift in wage growth and further declines in employment growth, alongside clear signs of weaker- than- expected headline and food inflation in September, are needed for the BoE to ease in November. Tighter fiscal policy at the Autumn budget would likely pose downside growth risks into 2026, but given the OBR needs 10 weeks to prepare forecasts and with no budget date announced yet, it is more likely that an Autumn budget will be delivered after the November \(6^{\mathrm{th}}\) MPC meeting. MPC OIS prices around 5bp of easing for November, a cumulative 10bp by the end of this year and just about 25bp of easing by next March (Figure 2). We keep received Nov25 MPC OIS given the limited easing priced as we wait to see labour market and inflation data over the coming months, but we do see a heightened chance that the BoE skips easing in November.

IYxI Y SONIA is modestly higher over the past few weeks and is just above the \(3.60\%\) level, close to the highs since early June. Current levels look modestly cheap vs our expected BoE terminal rate of \(3.50\%\) and are around 18bp cheap on a relative basis vs 1Yx1Y SOFR (Figure 3), with over 130bp of Fed easing priced by the end of 2026 and 1Yx1Y SOFR just above \(3.0\%\) , its lowest level since October 2024. However, the relationship between 1Yx1Y SONIA and 1Yx1Y SOFR has been weakening over the past few months (Figure 4). We think the BoE could still ease policy rates in 1Q26, even if it skips a November ease, and still see neutral at around \(3.50\%\) , which likely limits how much 1Yx1Y SONIA can cheapen. We shift to a bullish bias on 1Yx1Y SONIA as we expect 1Yx1Y SONIA to range- trade around the 3.50- 3.55% level.
Figure 3: 1Yx1Y SONIA looks 20bp cheap on a release basis vs 1Yx1Y SOFR on a 12M regression basis...
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 5: We have a tactical fronts/reds SONIA curve flattening bias given our bullish view on 1Yx1Y SONIA
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 4: ...although the relationship between 1Yx1Y SONIA and 1Yx1Y SOFR has been weakening over the past few months

The 1Y/1Yx1Y SONIA curve has steepened as 1Yx1Y SONIA has sold off over the past few weeks, with the fronts/reds SONIA curve close to its steepest levels since mid- January this year. On a 3M regression basis, the 1Y/1Yx1Y SONIA curve looks fair value vs 1Yx1Y SONIA (Figure 5) and we see potential for modest fronts/reds flattening given our bullish bias on 1Yx1Y SONIA.
Figure 6: 10Y gilt yields look close to fair value vs 10Y UST and adjusting for relative 2Yx1Y rate differentials
\(*10Y\) gilt \(= 1.07^{*}10Y\) UST \(+0.5^{*}(2Yx1Y\) SONIA-2Yx1Y SOFR)-0.28.R-squ: \(90\%\) std.error:7bp Source: J.P. Morgan.

10Y gilt yields are slightly higher over the past two weeks, having sold off to around \(4.75\%\) before falling back to just above the \(4.70\%\) level. The date for an Autumn budget has not yet been announced, and will likely be mid- November at the earliest, but the past couple of weeks have seen the government float various tax- raising ideas to plug the current fiscal shortfall, including introducing capital gains on the sale of primary residences, lowering the tax- free lump sum withdrawal threshold of pension savings and applying National Insurance to landlord's rental income. Details are far from clear, but applying some or all of these
along with freezing income tax thresholds from 2029 could raise \(\sim \pm 15\mathrm{bn}\)

This would likely plug a large part of our estimated £20bn budget shortfall, but we think this would be unlikely to materially reduce fiscal term premia uncertainty currently priced into the curve. In our view, unless the budget headroom is significantly increased above the £10bn from the prior budget then markets will be wary of how quickly any small headroom rebuild could be eroded again into a spring Budget if yields were to rise and/or GDP continue to undershoot OBR forecasts. 10Y gilt yields are towards the top end of their 3M ranges, but from a relative valuation standpoint 10Y gilt yields look close to fair value on a cross- market basis vs 10Y USTs and adjusting for relative 2Yx1Y SONIA- 2Yx1Y SOFR spread (Figure 6). The upcoming syndication of a new Oct2035 gilt expected next week will provide an interesting gauge of investor appetite for intermediate gilts against the backdrop of the recent fiscal noise. We stay neutral on 10Y duration.

Further out the curve, 30Y gilt yields are close to \(5.6\%\) and are at multi- decade highs (since 1998) with gilt forwards in the 15- 30Y sector of the curve well above the \(6.0\%\) level (Figure 7); however, we don't see current levels offering much value given the absence of structural investor demand. The 10s/30s gilt curve is little changed over the past couple of weeks and remains at multi- year steep levels, but we retain a 10s/30s steepening bias.
Figure 7: Long-end par gilt forwards in the 15-30Y sector are well above the \(6\%\) level
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 8: Historically, the 10s/30s gilt curve has exhibited seasonal steepening around the start of September, in contrast to the 10s/30s Bund and UST curves
Source: J.P. Morgan.

We note that the 10s/30s gilt curve has on average exhibited seasonal steepening from the start of September over the past five years, whereas the 10s/30s Bund and 10s/30s UST curves have tended to flatten (Figure 8). This likely reflects a typical pick- up in long- end gilt issuance after the summer lull. On a relative basis, we note that the 10s/30s gilt curve remains too steep on our valuation framework vs the level of 1Yx1Y SONIA, 30Y gilt yields and adjusting for the 10s/30s gilt curve (Figure 9), close to its steepest relative levels since late 2024. The DMO announced the issuance calendar from October – December on Friday, which will see two outright auctions at the long end of the curve and a planned 15Y syndication (Figure 10), in addition to the two long- end auctions scheduled in September. Long- end supply/demand dynamics remain unclear, in our view, and given the seasonal dynamics
and the potential for fiscal/issuance term premia uncertainty to remain elevated ahead of the autumn budget, we do not look to fade the outright and relative steepness in the 10s/30s gilt curve.
Figure 9: The 10s/30s gilt curve remains steep on a relative basis but we do not fade and maintain a steepening bias
Residual\\* from regressing 10s/30s gilt curve vs. 1Yx1Y SONIA, 30Y gilt yields and 10s/30s UST curve; past 12M, bp
Figure 10: The DMO has 4 long-end auctions and one long-end syndication planned up to the end of this calendar year DMO planned issuance calendar until end-2025, sizes JPMorgan estimates

Front- end swap spreads have been modestly wider over the past couple of weeks, with 10Y swap spreads little changed (Figure 11). 10Y swap spreads have traded in a 2bp range over the past couple of weeks and remain close to their narrowest levels since mid- January. However, on a relative valuation basis, 10Y swap spreads remain fair value vs the level of yields and adjusting volatility and the size of the BoE APF (Figure 12). We think 10Y swap spreads can continue to range trade in the near term but we maintain a medium- term modest narrowing bias as the size of the BoE APF continues to decline.
Figure 11: Front-end swap spreads modestly wider with 10Y swap spreads little changed over the past couple of weeksGilt swap spread level and change since 1 Aug, bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 12: 10Y swap spreads are close to their narrowest levels YTD but look fair value vs the level of yields and adjusting for volatility and size of BoE APF
\(^{\ast}10Y\) swap spread \(= 0.05^{\ast}10Y\) SONIA \(^{+}0.01^{\ast}3M\times 10Y\) vol \(+0.0003^{\ast}\) APF - 1.1. R-squ \(78\%\) , std. error: 3bp Source: J.P. Morgan.
